title: Fugitive Xavier Dupont de Ligonnès is not man arrested in Glasgow
text:
Officers arrested a man at Glasgow Airport but it is not Xavier Dupont de Ligonnès

A man arrested at Glasgow Airport is not the French aristocrat suspecting of murdering his family eight years ago.

The twist comes as officers thought they had finally tracked down fugitive Xavier Dupont de Ligonnès.

A ‘partial’ fingerprint sample led to speculation that the case that has transfixed France might finally be solved.

But a DNA test proved it is not the 58-year-old, who vanished after his family were shot dead in April 2011.

Xavier Dupont de Ligonnès was last seen in April 2011 (Picture: AFP)

De Ligonnes went on the run after the bodies of Agnes, 49, and children Tomas, 21, Arthur, 18, Anne, 16, and Benoit, 13, were found buried in the garden of the family house in Nantes, western France.

Alongside them were their two pet Labradors, Jules and Léon.

There has been speculation about what happened to the aristocrat with several believing he has since died.

However, a number of unconfirmed sightings mean that the prosecution has never closed the case.

French police are said to have picked out the suspect at Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris on Friday afternoon.

But there was not enough time to seize him and so they alerted British police who made an arrest when the suspect’s Easyjet flight landed in Glasgow.

People hold the coffin of a member of the Dupont de Ligonnès family during the funeral ceremony on April 28, 2011 in the French western city of Nantes (Picture: AFP)

A finger print test partially matched those of the alleged killer and a DNA test was ordered.

But a French police source said: ‘DNA checks have shown that the man arrested in Glasgow is not Xavier Dupont de Ligonnes.’

Police in Scotland have not released any details of the man they did arrest.

The De Ligonnès family (from top L) Xavier Dupont de Ligonnès, his wife Agnes, and children Thomas, Arthur, Anne and Benoit (Picture: AFP)

For years France has been gripped by the question of how De Ligonnes had disappeared without trace, with some suggesting he may have killed himself.

Hundreds of reported sightings only added to the mystery.

Last year police searched underground caves and an abandoned potassium mine in the area around Roquebrune-sur-Argens, in the south of France following a tip-off.

De Ligonnes was last officially seen on a CCTV camera in April 2011 walking in the countryside in the south of France.

In the months before, he had inherited a .22 rifle from his father and receipts found at the home revealed he had bought a silencer, a spade and other equipment that could have been used in the murders.

The bodies of De Ligonnès wife, four children and family pets were found in the back garden (Picture: AFP)

French prosecutors said he killed all five of his victims in a ‘methodical execution,’ shooting them each twice in the head.

He is believed to have covered them in quicklime and wrapped them in sheets before burying them under concrete.

De Ligonnes, who ran a number of internet businesses, was said to be having financial problems and a mistress in Paris was among those asking for money.

He disappeared telling friends he was a US secret agent who was being taken into witness protection.

Neighbours reported to the police that they had not seen any of the family for more than three weeks.

The murders transfixed France (Picture: AP)

Detectives who visited initially found a severed leg under the garden terrace, and then uncovered the bodies of those who had been killed.

Prosecutors never ruled out the possibility that he was living rough or being sheltered by friends or members of his extended family, who own country homes around France.

The family say he is innocent of the murders and were being kept informed of the arrest in Scotland.

A picture showing Benoit Dupont de Ligonnès, one of the five family members murdered at their home in Nantes (Picture: AFP)

De Ligonnès originally came from Versailles, home of the pre-Revolutionary kings and queens of France, and was technically a count who could trace his lineage back generations.

In confiscated emails he said that he considered himself to be part of a Roman Catholic elite which was superior to ‘the masses’.

‘I think I’ve got a superiority complex, you could call it that,’ he wrote.

‘But it’s based on a simple observation: I belong to a group of people who are intelligent, determined, balanced and in good moral and physical health.

‘Such people are rare compared to the masses.’
